Elisa Maia'' * '''South Africa''' ''John Bradley'' ''Marie DuToit'' * '''Sweden''' ''Christer Gruvberg'' * '''USA''' * [http://www.nationalmicroscalecc.org] ''NMCC in USA '' * [http://www.microscale.org USA] * [http://www.smallscalechemistry.colostate.edu USA] * [http://mattson.creighton.edu USA] *''Kenneth M. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox research institute |name = National Balloon Facility |motto = |logo = |image = TIFR balloon facilityogo.png |established = 1961 |research_field = [[Research balloon]]ing |head_label = Chairperson |head = Prof. Devendra Ojha |staff = |budget = |operating_agency = {{hlist |[[TIFR]] |[[ISRO]]}} |affiliations = |address = TIFR Balloon Facility,
ECIL PO |city = [[Hyderabad, Telangana|Hyderabad]] |province = {{nowrap|[[Telangana]]}} |country = [[India]] |zipcode = 500 062 |website = [http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/index.html tifr.res.in/~bf/index.html] }} The '''National Balloon Facility''', also known as the TIFR Balloon Facility, is a stratospheric-balloon launch base under the joint management of the [[Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] (TIFR) and the [[Indian Space Research Organisation]] (ISRO). This institute is located at [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] near [[Electronics Corporation of India Limited]] (ECIL).{{Cite web|url=http://stratocat.com.ar/bases/31e.htm|title=Stratospheric balloon launch bases and sites|publisher=StratoCat|date=12 October 2010|accessdate=19 October 2010}} Being the only major balloon facility in the world close to the [[Magnetic dip#Explanation|geomagnetic equator]], this facility is extensively used by researchers from all over the world.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/about%20us.html|title=NBF History|publisher=TIFR|accessdate=19 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031029142857/http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/about%20us.html|archivedate=29 October 2003|df=dmy-all}} ==History== Ballooning activity in India was prompted by research into atmospheric exploration and cosmic ray studies. During the 1940s, Dr. [[Homi J. Bhabha]] of TIFR started sending balloons up to an altitude of 25 km to study secondary cosmic radiation. Due to unique geographic reasons [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] was selected for stratospheric balloon launches. After various diplomatic meetings arrangements were made by US and Indian organisations to jointly launch balloons from Hyderabad. The first launch had support of Air Force Cambridge Research Laboratory (AFCRL) and TIFR. The launches were carried out from two locations. US balloons were launched from [[Begumpet Airport]] and Indian balloons from [[Osmania University]] Campus. The first balloon was launched on 2 February 1961. During the first stage of the facility's operation, forty balloons were launched. After five years all the facilities were consolidated at Osmania University and under management of [[National Center for Atmospheric Research]] & TIFR and around 170 balloons were launched. After a few years with increasing demands for balloon flights, a relatively low population density and proximity to the geomagnetic equator, a permanent site at Hyderabad near ECIL was selected. However, presently due to rapid development this facility is today surrounded by several population settlements: by the [[Cherlapally Central Jail]] in the east; [[Kamala Nagar, Hyderabad|Kamala Nagar]] in the west; and [[Electronics Corporation of India]] Ltd. in the south.{{Cite web|url=http://stratocat.com.ar/bases/31e.htm|title=Stratospheric balloon launch bases and sites|publisher=StratoCat|date=12 October 2010|accessdate=19 October 2010}} ==Activities== The campus contains a complete balloon manufacturing facility. The institute conducts balloon-based scientific experiments in X-ray and [[Infrared Astronomy]], and in [[Aeronomy]]. Balloons from this facility are launched twice in a year, i.e. in summer and winter. NBF also regularly monitors and analyses local weather at [[tropospheric]] and [[stratospheric]] altitudes, required for making decisions about balloon launches. Under the High Altitude Balloon Development Project, a 61,000m³ indigenously developed balloon penetrated into the Mesosphere on 7 January 2014, for the first time in India. Until that time, only balloons from USA and Japan had accomplished this feat.[http://www.tifr.res.in/~bf/HAA_Record.html HAA Records] ==See also== * [[Balloons for X-ray astronomy]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Research institutes in Telangana}} [[Category:Research institutes in Hyderabad, India]] [[Category:Atmospheric sciences]] [[Category:Tata Institute of Fundamental Research]] [[Category:Atmospheric sounding]]

page.title: Power-control theory of gender and delinquency

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{essay|date=January 2016}}
In [[criminology]], the '''power-control theory of gender and delinquency''' (abbreviated as the '''power-control theory''') holds the gender distribution of [[:wikt:delinquency|delinquency]] is caused by stratification from [[gender role|gender relations]] within the [[family]].<ref name="MessnerKrohn1989">{{Cite book|author1=Steven F. Messner|author2=Marvin D. Krohn|author3=Allen E. Liska|title=Theoretical integration in the study of deviance and crime: problems and propects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U0lS-wWM-BAC|accessdate=19 March 2010|date=August 1989|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-0000-5|page=213}}</ref> The [[social theory|theory]] seeks to explain [[gender]] differences in the rates of delinquency by attributing them to the level of social/parental control practiced. The theory states that the [[social class|class]], [[gender]], and type of family structure (e.g. [[egalitarian]] or [[patriarchal]]) will influence the severity of social/parental control practiced which will in turn set the "accepted norm" for the child/individual.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.soc.umn.edu/~uggen/4141lec18.pdf|title=41481lec18|date=2008-04-03|work=Powerpoint notes|pages=2|accessdate=19 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=J. Palumbo|first=Dennis |date=July 1997|title=CRIMINOLOGICAL CONTROVERSIES: A METHODOLOGICAL PRIMER|journal=Law and Politics Review|publisher=Department of Government & Politics, University of Maryland|volume= 7|issue= 7|pages=335–337|issn=1062-7421|url=http://www.bsos.umd.edu/gvpt/lpbr/subpages/reviews/HaganJ.htm}}</ref><ref name="Siegel2003">{{Cite book|author=Larry J. Siegel|title=Criminology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TQpNNH3O_OQC|accessdate=19 March 2010|year=2003|publisher=Wadsworth/Thomson Learning|isbn=978-0-534-52654-2|page=269}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=A. Bates|first=Kristin |author2=Christopher D. Bader |author3=F. Carson Mencken |year=2003|title=Family Structure, Power-Control Theory, and Deviance: Extending Power-control Theory to Include Alternate Family Forms|journal=Western Criminology Review|volume=4|issue=3|pages=170–190|issn=1096-4886|url=http://wcr.sonoma.edu/v4n3/Manuscripts/bates.pdf}}</ref> This norm will in turn control the level of delinquency by the individual.
Power-control theory differs from other control theories that view crime as a cause of low [[social status]] (cited from book). This theory compares gender and parental control mechanisms in two different types of families; patriarchal and egalitarian to explain the differences in self-reported male and female misconduct. In patriarchal families, traditional gender roles were in practice, where the father would work outside the home, and the mother would be responsible for the child rearing. In egalitarian families, the household roles were shared equally between mothers and fathers.<ref>O'Grady 2007, p. 110.</ref>
The theory was originally posited by [[John Hagan (sociologist)|John Hagan]] and further developed by [[A. R. Gillis]] and [[John Simpson (sociologist)|John Simpson]] at the [[University of Toronto]].<ref name="clarify and extend">{{Cite journal|last1=Hagan|first1=John |first2=A. R. |last2=Gillis |first3=John |last3=Simpson|date=January 1990|title=Clarifiying and Extending Power-Control Theory|journal=The American Journal of Sociology|publisher=University of Toronto|volume= 95|issue= 4|pages=1024–1037|jstor=2780649|doi=10.1086/229384}}</ref>
==Development==
The power control theory was developed through a series of self-report surveys that was administered to high school students and their parents in suburban Toronto. Hagan and his colleagues contended that gender and the social class of the students' parents affected how much freedom these students had. For example, coming of age as they argued, was a more limiting experience than growing up as a male. Thereby, they found that the amount of power a parent had in the workplace was related to the control displayed in the household over their teenaged children. Moreover, parents who had the types of jobs where they must supervise the activities of subordinates also tended to be relatively tolerant of the trouble-making behaviour of their children, especially of their sons. This meant that teenaged boys are freer to deviate than teenaged girls. This study also found, focusing on relatively minor forms of deviance such as shoplifting and breaking street lights, that middle-class youth actually were freer to deviate than working-class youth.<ref name="O'Grady 2007, p. 111">O'Grady 2007, p. 111.</ref>
==Limitations==
According to Julian Tanner, he offers two interesting critical comments. Though the power control theory effectively explains common delinquency among ordinary youth, it does not explain violent and repetitive crime and, therefore, the power control theory cannot predict such behavior. In addition, the power control theory suggests that parents in egalitarian households are more likely to raise females as delinquent than a female growing up in a patriarchal family; however, UCR (uniform crime report) data shows that the opposite association exists and that the involvement in female labor force is actually related to lower levels of female delinquency. Also, after years of refining the power control theory, theorists have found the notion that mothers being more controlling over their daughters are more likely to be found in egalitarian families than patriarchal families, which is the opposite relationship the power control theory would likely predict.
When the theory was refined over the years, Singer and Levine (1988) found mixed support for the theory in their early attempts to test this theory. While mothers were seen to be more controlling over their daughters than their sons, the authors also found this to be more so with egalitarian than patriarchal families, which is a finding opposite to what power control theory would predict.<ref name="O'Grady 2007, p. 111"/>
==Theory extended beyond family==
The theory has been extended into adult social roles as well. Stratified behaviors typically associated with males, particularly those in authoritative positions, are now being seen more frequently in females attaining powerful roles. And like their male counterparts, their power is used to control those persons in subordinate roles, as indicated by the rise in reports of sexual harassment (cougar syndrome) and cronyism.
Despite the explanation of social roles, there has not been a feminist theory that is fully developed to explain for the uniqueness of female criminality. While males are reported to be more involved in every type of crime, females tend to be arrested for considerably minor property crimes. This is due to the idea that the character and level of female crime is not consistent with the traditional sociological explanations of crime.<ref>O'Grady 2007, p. 112.</ref>
==References==
{{Reflist}} *O'Grady, William (2007). ''Crime in Canadian Context'', Oxford University Press, p. 110-112.
==Further reading==
* {{Cite book|author1=John Hagan|author2=A. R. Gillis|author3=David Brownfield|title=Criminological controversies: a methodological primer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FnPmnt4h32kC|date=30 May 1996|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=978-0-8133-1083-1}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100306053448/http://www.apsu.edu/oconnort/crim/crimtheory15.htm Conflict Criminology], Austin Peay State University * [http://sociologyindex.com/power_control_theory.htm POWER-CONTROL THEORY], Sociology Index
[[Category:Power (social and political)]] [[Category:Control (social and political)]] [[Category:Gender studies]] [[Category:Law enforcement theory]] [[Category:Sociological theories]]

{{Infobox organization|name=Project ''Piaba''|image=File:Paracheirodon cardinalis.JPG|alt=A slender fish, seen from the side, with its head at the lower left and its tail at the upper right. The fish is a deep red, with a light, glowing blue stripe running from its eye to the base of its tail. The background is a brownish gravel with a mossy green plant.|caption=A [[cardinal tetra]], or ''piaba''|established={{Start date and age|1991}}|founders=Ning Labbish Chao, Gregory Prang|type=[[Non-governmental organization]]|status=Charity||purpose=Conservation of the [[Amazon River basin]]|headquarters=[[New England Aquarium]]|leader_title=Director|leader_name=Scott Dowd|slogan=''Buy a Fish, Save a Tree!''|website=http://projectpiaba.org/}}{{DISPLAYTITLE:Project ''Piaba''}} '''Project ''Piaba''''' ({{IPA-pt|pi:ˈɑ:bɑ:|pron}}) is a [[fishery]] initiative located on the [[Rio Negro (Amazon)|Rio Negro]] tributary of the [[Amazon river]]. The program both promotes and researches [[Sustainability|sustainable]] [[aquarium]] [[fishkeeping|pet fish]] collection and its [[Human impact on the environment|impact on the environment]]. The name of the project comes from the [[Brazilian Portuguese]] word, ''piaba'', which means "little fish",<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://discovermagazine.com/2013/april/13-buy-a-fish-save-a-tree|title = Buy a Fish, Save a Tree|last = Montgomery|first = Sy|date = 21 March 2013|journal = Discover Magazine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 6 August 2015|volume = 34|issue = 3|pages = 26–27}}</ref> referring specifically to the [[cardinal tetra]] (''Paracheirodon axelrodi'').<ref name=":2"/> Project ''Piaba'' is an ongoing project with annual research expeditions to the Rio Negro region.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://www.neaq.org/conservation_and_research/projects/endangered_species_habitats/project_piaba.php|title = Project Piaba|date = |accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = New England Aquarium|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Because of the sustainable nature of the project, its slogan is "Buy a Fish, Save a Tree!"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://projectpiaba.org/who-we-are/history/|title = Project Piaba History|date = |accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Project Piaba|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Background == Many ornamental [[freshwater aquarium]] fish, including the cardinal tetra and the [[Discus (fish)|discus]] (''Symphysodon'' ssp.), are sourced from the [[Amazon River basin]] area.<ref name=":1"/> The Rio Negro region is the home of more than 100 different species of fish that are important to the pet fish trade.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.feow.org/ecoregions/details/rio_negro|title = 314: Rio Negro|date = |accessdate = 6 August 2015|website = Freshwater Ecoregions of the World|publisher = The Nature Conservancy|last = Petry|first = Paulo|last2 = Hales|first2 = Jennifer}}</ref> In fact several species, including cardinal tetras, show the adaptive trait of [[iridescence]] which may provide lower visibility in a [[Blackwater river|blackwater]] environment.<ref name=":0"/>
Project ''Piaba'' started with an ecological [[Measurement|baseline]] study of the region which was conducted in 1989 by a group of researchers and students from the [[Federal University of Amazonas|Universidade do Amazonas]] (UA) and the National Institute of Amazon Research (INPA).<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.ornamental-fish-int.org/research-support/projeto-piaba|title = Project Piaba|last = Chao|first = Ning Labbish|date = May 2002|journal = Ornamental Fish International|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 6 August 2015|issue = 39|last2 = Prang|first2 = Gregory}}</ref> This initial survey discovered and documented the importance of the fish trade to the local [[economy]] and it led the researchers to wonder about the impact the fishing had on the environment.<ref name=":3" />
The ornamental fish trade in the Rio Negro region is considered "substantial by local standards representing approximately US$ 3 million per year with over 30 million live fish exported annually."<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Phylogeography of a flooded forest specialist fish from central Amazonia based on intron DNA: the cardinal tetra Paracheirodon axelrodi|url = http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1365-2427.2009.02172.x|journal = Freshwater Biology|date = 2009-01-01|volume = 54|issue = 6|doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2427.2009.02172.x|first = GEORGINA M.|last = COOKE|first2 = NING L.|last2 = CHAO|first3 = LUCIANO B.|last3 = BEHEREGARAY|subscription = yes}}</ref> Approximately 40,000 people in the region, many of them ''caboclos'' (river-dwelling families) are dependent on the income from their fisheries.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://en.microcosmaquariumexplorer.com/wiki/Buy_A_(Wild)_Fish_-_Save_A_Tree|title = Buy a (Wild) Fish - Save a Tree|date = |accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Microcosm: Aquarium Explorer|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Development == In the 1950s, [[Herbert R. Axelrod]] and Willi Schwarz had begun shipping aquarium fish out of [[Barcelos, Amazonas|Barcelos]] in Brazil.<ref name=PracFish>[https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/news/fishkeeping-news/articles/2017/5/30/obituary-dr-herbert-r-axelrod "Obituary: Dr. Herbert R. Axelrod"]. ''Practical Fishkeeping'', 30 May 2017. Archived 20 June 2017.</ref> In 1991, Ning Labbish Chao and Gregory Prang founded Project ''Piaba'' in order to support the local fisheries and in concert with them, help protect the habitat of collected fishes.<ref name=":3" /> Because of the "gentle" way the fish are caught and the fact that most of the fish caught for the aquarium trade are short-lived and would naturally die out during the dry season, the ecological impact of catching the fish is considered minimal.<ref name=":1" /> The fish are also not caught by fish farmers during their breeding season.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fishchannel.com/fish-species/freshwater-profiles/cardinal-tetra-2.aspx|title = Cardinal Tetra Fish Stats|date = |accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Fish Channel|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The cardinal tetra, especially, is considered a [[renewable resource]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.takepart.com/article/2013/06/24/endangered-fish-dna-barcoding|title = Can DNA Barcoding Really Save Endangered Fish?|last = Conniff|first = Richard|date = 24 June 2013|work = Take Part|access-date = 7 August 2015|via = }}</ref> Project ''Piaba'' assesses the sustainability of the species farmed in the Rio Negro area by using the "[[F-distribution|F value]]" which estimates the portion of the catch from the total biomass.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.opefe.com/PPiaba_webver.doc|title = Forever 'Project Piaba'|date = 2008|accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Oregon Piranha Exotic Fish Exhibit (OPEFE)|publisher = |last = Chao|first = Ning Labbish}}</ref>
The center of the Rio Negro aquarium trade, [[Barcelos, Amazonas|Barcelos]], now celebrates ornamental fish in a festival held every January in conjunction with the annual research expedition of Project ''Piaba''.<ref name=":1" /> A stadium, known as Piabodrome, was even built for the festival.<ref name=":1" /> The first festival took place in 1994 and a permanent exhibit highlighting the fish was installed in Barcelos by Project ''Piaba'' that same year.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.tfhmagazine.com/details/articles/hope-along-the-rio-negro-part-1-the-view-from-manaus.htm|title = Hope Along the Rio Negro Part 1: The View From Manaus|last = Carey|first = Randy|date = March 2007|journal = The Fish Hobbyist Magazine|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 7 August 2015}}</ref> Money donated by [[Ichthyology|ichthyologist]], [[Herbert R. Axelrod|Herbert Axelrod]], helped support a lab and then later, the Centre for Aquatic Conservation which has helped educate, support research and awareness of the project.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/content.php?sid=6176|title = Cardinals Answer Prayers|date = 2 January 2014|accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Practical Fishkeeping|publisher = |last = Hill|first = Nathan}}</ref> The Centre was first opened in 1997.<ref name=":3" /> Other funds have come from the Association of Ornamental Fish Breeders and Exporters of Amazonas (ACEPOAM) for research on both the fish and the welfare of the fish farmers.<ref name=":3" />
== Structure == Scott Dowd is the current director of Project ''Piaba''.<ref name=":2" /> He leads the yearly expeditions with experts from around the world, volunteers and even family visiting the Amazon region.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.boston.com/sponsored/extra/sponsored-ne-aquarium-fishstory|title = The Life Aquatic|last = Montgomery|first = Sy|date = 13 April 2015|work = The Boston Globe|access-date = 7 August 2015|via = Boston.com}}</ref>
The project has acted as a case study for other, similar projects.<ref name=":2" /> Areas such as the [[Western Ghats]] in [[India]] and areas of [[Bali]] are beginning to use similar practices in order to make money from the fish trade and sustain the environment of the fish.<ref name=":1" /> Project ''Piab''a is often used to show how groups can support the environment while providing economic stimulus to a poor region of the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.petproductnews.com/July-2015/International-Waters-Industry-Unfairly-Attacked--Again/|title = International Waters: Industry Unfairly Attacked... Again!|last = Dawes|first = John|date = July 2015|work = Pet Product News|access-date = 7 August 2015|via = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.aza.org/Membership/detail.aspx?id=30396|title = How to Create Protected Areas and Provide for Exhibits in the Future by Promoting a Socially and Environmentally Beneficial Aquarium Fish Trade|date = |accessdate = |website = Association of Zoos and Aquariums|publisher = |last = Firchau|first = Beth|last2 = Dowd|first2 = Scott|last3 = Tlusty|first3 = Michael}}</ref> In addition, the sustainable sourcing of fish is also a stimulus to the idea of "beneficial home fishkeeping" which emphasizes proper fish care, which, in turn supports those who catch the fish in the wild.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/content.php?sid=6702|title = New Group to Examine Benefits of Fishkeeping Hobby|last = |first = |date = 27 March 2015|work = Practical Fishkeeping|access-date = 7 August 2015|via = }}</ref> When there is no incentive to fish, individuals in the Rio Negro area turn to less-environmentally friendly means of support, such as [[logging]] or [[Ranch|cattle ranching]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.kearsney.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=518:project-piaba-trip-to-the-amazon-&catid=62:latest-news&Itemid=207|title = Matt Needham's Amazon Trip Follow-Up|date = 2003|accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Kearsney Old Boys|publisher = |last = Needham|first = Matt}}</ref> In fact, Project ''Piaba'' aims to actively discourage domestic farming of fish which are also sustainable resources, like the cardinal tetra, because it will take the financial incentive away from protecting the rain forest of the Rio Negro area.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Savages and Beasts: The Birth of the Modern Zoo|last = Rothfels|first = Nigel|publisher = Johns Hopkins University Press|year = 2002|isbn = 0801869102|location = Baltimore, Maryland|pages = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Fish Conservation: A Guide to Understanding and Restoring Global Aquatic Biodiversity and Fishery Resources|last = Helfman|first = Gene S.|publisher = Island Press|year = 2007|isbn = 9781559635950|location = Washington, D.C.|pages = 401–402}}</ref>
== Legacy == The project has the support of aquariums and [[zoo]]s around the world<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.pittsburghzoo.org/Conservation/BeyondOurOwnBackyard|title = Beyond Our Own Backyard|date = |accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Pittsburgh Zoo and PPG Aquarium|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.umich.edu/~esupdate/julaug2000/dowd.htm|title = Conservation Spotlight|date = 2000|accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Endangered Species Update|publisher = School of Natural Resources and Environment|last = Dowd|first = Scott|last2 = Tlusty|first2 = Michael}}</ref> and also from the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|International Union for the Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://blog.kendall-press.com/2014/11/project-piaba/|title = Sustainability, Community and Project Piaba|date = 13 November 2014|accessdate = 7 August 2015|website = Kendall Press|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://projectpiaba.org/ Official Page] * [https://vimeo.com/124670986 Project ''Piaba'': For Ornamental Fish] (video)
{{Aquarium |state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Fishkeeping]] [[Category:Ecological experiments]] [[Category:Environmental research]] [[Category:Rio Negro (Amazon)]] [[Category:Sustainable fisheries]] [[Category:Fisheries science]] [[Category:Conservation in Brazil]] [[Category:Amazon rainforest]]

{{Orphan|date=November 2015}}
[[File:HelenHillListenTotheRoosterFeb06.jpg|thumb|We may appear to be listening when we are not]] '''Pseudo-listening''' is a type of '''non-listening''' that consists of appearing attentive in conversation while actually ignoring or only partially listening to the other speaker.<ref>http://www.yourdictionary.com/pseudolisten</ref> The intent of pseudo-listening is not to listen, but to cater to some other personal need of the listener.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Messages: The Communication Skill Book|last = McKay|first = Matthew|publisher = New Harbinger Publications|year = 2009|isbn = 978-1-57224-592-1|location = Oakland, Ca|pages = 6}}</ref> The word pseudo-listening is a compound word composed of the individual words [[Pseudo-|pseudo]] (a Greek root meaning "not real or genuine"<ref>{{Cite web|title = pseudo {{!}} not real or genuine|url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pseudo|website = www.merriam-webster.com|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref>), and [[listening]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = the definition of listening|url = http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/listening?s=t|website = Dictionary.com|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref> An example of pseudo-listening is trying to multitask by talking on the phone while watching television or completing work.<ref name="Burch">{{Cite book|title = Interpersonal Communication: Building Your Foundations for Success|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=n9Txn-cKH80C&pg=PA52&dq=pseudo+listening&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAmoVChMIy8qOtf21yAIVSD4-Ch1-NABD#v=onepage&q=pseudo%2520listening&f=false|publisher = Kendall Hunt|date = 2004-08-01|isbn = 9780757509544|first = Michelle|last = Burch|first2 = Michelle Burch|last2 = Coleman}}</ref> Pseudo-listening is the most ineffective way to communicate because after the conversation one will not have retained much of the information that was said.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Llangari|first1=Edwing|title=Pseudolistening|url=http://edwingllangari.efoliomn.com/pseudolistening|website=Edwing Llangari|publisher=myeflio|accessdate=10/9/2015}}</ref>
== Possible reasons ==
# Listening for ways someone can reject you.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chapter 9 Summary|url = http://faculty.mdc.edu/mroqueta/ch9summary.htm|website = Miami Dade College, Dr. Mildred Roqueta|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref> # Forming your response to the speaker instead of focusing on what is being said. # Preoccupation, when there is too much on the mind of the listener, so that they cannot listen.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The 1973 annual handbook for group facilitators|last = Pfeiffer|first = William|publisher = John Wiley & Sons, Incorporated|year = 1973|isbn = 9780787903800|location = San Diego|pages = }}</ref> # Preexisting familiarity with the topic of conversation, which results in less effort to actively listen. # Only listening for information you want to hear, giving little attention to the rest. # Listening only for the flaws in their argument in order to gain an advantage over the speaker. # Social pressure to be courteous to those speaking. # Hope that they will believe you are listening and return the favor. # An effort to build others' views of you. # Desire not to hurt someone who is sharing experiences.
== In comparison to active listening ==
Individuals who are pseudo-listening may include minimal encouragers to compensate for their non-listening, such as nodding their heads, looking at the speaker, smiling at the appropriate times, and displaying other aspects of paying attention, so it may be difficult at times to distinguish between active listening and pseudo-listening. Similarly, broad answers or responses that are not relevant to the topic at hand also give away a pseudo-listener. These responses are known as '''tangential responses''' and often run alongside the topic being discussed, but ultimately have nothing to do with the main topic of the discussion.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wood|first1=Julia|title=Interpersonal Communication|date=2014|publisher=Cengage Learning|location=Boston, MA|isbn=978-1-285-44583-0|page=173}}</ref>
Proper listening is needed to internalize and comprehend material; without this developed skill, there is potential for either pseudo-listening or a total lack of listening. A person who is truly listening may display certain body language such as maintaining eye contact or positioning their body towards the speaker.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Communication and Interpersonal Relationships - Counseling and Health Services|url = http://drexel.edu/healthservices/resources/students/communication/|website = Counseling and Health Services|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref> Real listening is done with the intent to understand a person's perspective, enjoy a person's company, learn new information, or provide assistance or comfort, among other things.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Intercultural communication: a teaching and learning framework {{!}} LLAS Centre for Languages, Linguistics and Area Studies|url = https://www.llas.ac.uk/resources/paper/1303|website = www.llas.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref>
== How it affects communication ==
Pseudo-listening is most common in face-to-face communication, but it can also be expressed through phone calls, text messages and e-mails.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Listen Like You Mean It|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jennifer-rosen/listen-like-you-mean-it_b_6136092.html|website = The Huffington Post|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref> Effective communication is dependent upon both the receiver and the sender to be fully aware of what is being said and heard. When one person projects their thoughts, and the receiver of the message is only pretending to listen, poor communication and possibly misunderstanding often occur. Babies spend their first few years listening to people around them in order to learn language (Childs, Acott-Smith, & Curtis, 1999). According to Edwing Llangari people spend around half their lives listening to others.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://edwingllangari.efoliomn.com/pseudolistening|title = Edwing Llangari}}</ref> An article from University of Colorado states that poor listening skills make good communication pretty much impossible to achieve. It says that, "no matter how much care one person or group takes to communicate their concerns, values, interests, or needs in a fair, clear, unthreatening way, if the listener is not willing to receive that information in that way, the communication will fail."<ref>{{Cite web|title = I’m Sorry What Were You Saying? {{!}} A Look At Interpersonal Communication|url = http://blogs.longwood.edu/matthewmcpartland/2012/10/25/im-sorry-what-were-you-saying/|website = blogs.longwood.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref>
=== With couples ===
There are many negative effects on romantic relationships caused by pseudo-listening. These effects can range from making romantic partners feel upset, inhibiting the partner's ability to effectively solve problems, encouraging an unhealthy dependence on the listener, raising the partner's level of stress, making the relationship, as a whole, less stable, causing the romantic partner to be less satisfied with the relationship, and even causing negative effects on the romantic partner's health.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What are the consequences when you don't listen well?|url = http://www.youmeworks.com/consequences.html|website = www.youmeworks.com|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref> It’s important to recognize that there are two parts to any conversation, the person doing the talking and the person who is trying to actively listen.
=== With parents and children ===
Among families, teenagers engage in pseudo-listening the most. Teenagers may engage in pseudo-listening because they feel they have better things to do.They may also tune into distractions and act like they are listening. In doing so, it is evident that they listen only when they want to listen.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.ncur20.com/presentations/13/1388/paper.pdf|title = The Tricky Transition: Communication in the Mother and Adolescent-Daughter Relationship|last = Kraemer|first = Ashley A.|date = 2006|journal = UW-Whitewater Wisconsin|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 2015-10-07}}</ref> Studies show that as people get older, pseudo-listening skills increase. An experiment was done on first-grade and second grade children to see if they could repeat what the teacher had been saying. 90% of first graders and 80% of the second-graders could do so; but when the experiment was repeated with teenagers, only 44% of junior high students and 28% of senior high students could repeat their teachers’ remarks.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Baba|first1=Josephine|title=OVERCOMING CHALLENGES TO EFFECTIVE LISTENING-Faulty listening behavious|url=http://wecommunication.blogspot.com/2015/09/overcoming-challenges-to-effective.html|accessdate=Oct 8, 2015}}</ref> It is important for parents to have good listening skills, because poor listening from parents can cause the child to be closed off.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ncur20.com/presentations/13/1388/paper.pdf|title = The Tricky Transition: Communication in the Mother and Adolescent-Daughter Relationship|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
=== In a classroom ===
[[File:Physical Sciences Classroom.jpg|thumb|Many students pseudolisten during class due to numerous distractions.]] Recent studies reveal that students rarely encounter curriculum focused on learning and developing the skill of listening. It is possible for a student to go through every level of education without ever having a class teaching them how to listen effectively in everyday life.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Who's Listening in the Classroom? A Research Paradigm.|url = http://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED407659|date = 1997-03-14|first = Charles H.|last = Swanson}}</ref> Often students fall victim to pseudo-listening because of all the distractions they have at their finger tips, such as phones, computers, social media, iPods, etc. Students will often pretend to be listening so that the professor of the class does not verbally chastise, or to avoid being perceived as rude. Effective listening from a teacher is a way of showing concern for their subordinates, which fosters cohesive bonds, commitment, and trust: this can help a class to pay attention and learn what is being taught.<ref name=":0" />
===Leaders===
Leadership often involves forming a commitment to the people one is leading, and a large part of this is related to active listening. Pseudo-listening undermines this commitment process and leads to ineffective leadership. Many people think they are listening to others all the time, and while they certainly may be hearing what these people are saying, they are engaging in pseudo-listening. Over time, pseudo-listening can not only weaken perceptions of one as a leader, but can contribute to problems active listening could otherwise fix and lead to barriers against success in an organization.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/236257286?accountid=14472|title = The People Side of Leadership: An Overlooked Opportunity|last = Leheney|first = Mark|date = 2008|journal = Public Manager|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 37|issue = 2|pages = 15–18}}</ref> On the job, we may need to appear interested in what others say because of their position.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Communication Mosaics: An Introduction to the Field of Communication|last = Wood|first = Julia|publisher = Cengage Learning|year = 2010|isbn = 9781111786366|location = |pages = 124}}</ref>
== Features that contribute == Things such as an accent, height, weight, scars, and even something as small as body posture can all contribute to an audience falling victim to pseudo-listening. Being self-conscious about some of these personal flaws as a speaker may inhibit the listeners experience. This lack of self-confidence could lead to other distractions made by the speaker.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How to Be Less Self-Conscious|url = http://psychcentral.com/blog/archives/2014/01/26/how-to-be-less-self-conscious/|website = Psych Central.com|accessdate = 2015-10-27}}</ref><nowiki/> While these physical flaws may lead to disinterest in the reader it could also contribute to nervous actions that may also distract the reader. A few examples of these nervous actions may include but are not limited to clenching your hands, adjusting your hair or clothing, and pacing back and forth while speaking.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 10 Public Speaking Habits To Avoid At All Costs|url = http://www.businessinsider.com/10-public-speaking-habits-to-avoid-2014-6|website = Business Insider|accessdate = 2015-10-27}}</ref> These actions may lead to a disinterest in the context of a speech and an elevated interest in the person speaking or the environment surrounding them.
Environmental factors such as lighting, temperature, and furniture can affect the attention of the audience in relation to what the speaker has to say. Lighting that is too dark can make an audience tired and consequently disinterested in what the speaker has to say. Temperature and seating arrangements can distract an audience by causing them discomfort, shifting their focus to their own annoyance. Being too far from a speaker can also cause the audience to lose focus because of a sort of "[[Hawthorne effect]]. Physiological noise can also lead to distractions that take an audiences attention from the speaker. This noise may range from ailments and illness, all the way to emotions like arousal. Both sides of the spectrum can affect the audiences attention, for example, a speaker giving a speech while under the illness of a cold will have a stuffy nose or a recurring cough, which can take the audience's focus from the speaker to his cold. The audience can also be influenced by their own lives by shifting their focus on what they will eat for lunch, losing or finding a job, personal relationships, etc. These can all overshadow the messages and ideas that the speaker is trying to deliver.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Listening|url = http://2012books.lardbucket.org/books/a-primer-on-communication-studies/s05-listening.html|website = 2012books.lardbucket.org|accessdate = 2015-10-10}}</ref>
=== Facial features as distractions ===
[[File:Matt Wiman Pointy Mustache.jpg|thumb|Try listening to anything this guy has to say - you might find yourself pseudolistening]] Because facial hair is a striking characteristic of one's face, people often notice and focus on an individual's facial hair. Because of this, listeners may fall victim to pseudolistening. Instead of making eye contact, listeners might focus on the speaker's mustache or beard instead of [[active listening|actively listening]]. Facial hair is distracting to both listeners and observers.This concept can also be applied to situations in which a person has something stuck in his teeth, has visible mucus in his nose, or has conspicuous piercings and tattoos on his face.
=== How to avoid it === Effective listening is crucial to proper communication in everyday life. However, active listening is not a natural process.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Are You Really Listening?|url = http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1108/02683949210018331|journal = Journal of Managerial Psychology|pages = 17–21|volume = 7|issue = 6|doi = 10.1108/02683949210018331|first = Marilyn M.|last = Helms|first2 = Paula J.|last2 = Haynes}}</ref> In fact, even people who consider themselves good listeners often only listen with 25% efficiency.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Effective Listening|url = http://www.wright.edu/~scott.williams/LeaderLetter/listening.htm|website = www.wright.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = 9 Things Good Listeners Do Differently|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/14/habits-of-good-listeners_n_5668590.html|website = The Huffington Post|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref> Active listening involves attentive body language, restating comments and emotions of the speaker, and repeating their ideas back in order to check comprehension accuracy.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Training Married Couples in Listening Skills: Effects on Behavior, Perceptual Accuracy and Marital Adjustment|jstor = 584144|journal = Family Relations|date = 1981-04-01|pages = 297–306|volume = 30|issue = 2|doi = 10.2307/584144|first = Diana R.|last = Garland}}</ref>
It is possible to improve your listening skills. Begin by observing your conversations, and pay special notice to the times you begin to get distracted or ignore the other person and see how it affects your relationships. Once you understand your patterns in conversations, it's easier to change the negative aspects of your conversations. There are three main guidelines everyone should follow if they want to become effective listeners. The most important guideline is being mindful, that is, being disciplined and committed when trying to listen. The next guideline is adapting to listening appropriately because it is beneficial to be skilled in many listening behaviors and to know when each is important. The final guideline to becoming an effective listener is listening actively.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Interpersonal Communication: Everyday Encounters|last = Wood|first = Julia|publisher = Cenage Learning|year = |isbn = 978-1-305-63452-7|location = Boston, Massachusetts|pages = 182–183}}</ref> To listen actively, keep eye contact with the speaker, nod when a message is understood, etc. Paraphrasing what was said in order to communicate to the speaker that you understood their message correctly will also improve listening skills.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://faculty.northseattle.edu/wholt/bus236/lessons/s05files/listen2.pdf|title = Active Listening: Hear What People are Really Saying|date = |accessdate = 10/7/2015|website = MindTools|publisher = MindTools|last = |first = }}</ref> A good tag phrase for paraphrasing is "What I'm hearing you say is...", followed by the question, "Is that right?" This combination of repeating back and asking for confirmation of accuracy frees the speaker to correct any previous ineffective communication.
=== Signs someone is not listening === One way to detect pseudolistening is eye fixation: in relaxed conversations, the eye tends to wander or look at other parts of your face. We also tend to smile at one another to reinforce that we agree with them and are listening. The pseudo-listener will do the same but will often smile for too long. During a conversation between two people, their bodies will face each other. A false listener, however, will not have engaged body language; instead, whether their feet face away or they sit next to rather than across from the other person, it is as if their body is trying to escape.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 7 Signs Someone's Not Listening To You|url = http://www.businessinsider.com/signs-someone-is-not-listening-2014-6|website = Business Insider|accessdate = 2015-10-09}}</ref>
=== Examples === * Ambushing: Waiting to trap the speaker in his/her own words or ideas; mostly used to support a belief or to prove something. * Assimilation to Prior Messages: Believing new messages relate to past messages; forgetting that communication changes. * Critical Listening: Not to be confused with defensive listening, critical listening is listening to analyze and understand the speaker's messages, written or spoken.<ref name="Burch"/> * Defensive Listening: A form of listening where the remarks by the speaker are taken personally, so the listener seeks a way to defend themselves against the perceived attack.<ref name="Burch"/> * Filling in the Gaps: After hearing the beginning, assuming that the information given is the whole story. * Insensitive Listening: Failing to notice hidden meanings or nonverbal cues.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Poor Listening Habits|url = http://www.theexecutiveadvisory.com/toolkit/poor_listenting_habits.html|website = www.theexecutiveadvisory.com|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref> * Insulated Listening: Avoiding certain topics. * Selective Listening: Only paying attention to what one is interested in while ignoring and avoiding the rest of the information given. * Stage-Hogging: Not really caring for what others have to say: only worried about yourself.
===False representations===
Auditory processing disorder is when a person "is perfectly aware of sounds" yet their brain abnormally deciphers the sounds. This could easily be confused with pseudo-listening because it effects a listeners' reading comprehension. The two differ because auditory processing disorder uncontrollable and unintentional, while pseudolistening is typically done purposely.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Communication]] [[Category:Behavioural sciences]]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Ruth Gates | birth_name = Ruth Deborah Gates | birth_date = {{Birth date|1962|3|28|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia|Akrotiri]], Cyprus | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|10|25|1962|3|28|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Kailua,_Honolulu_County,_Hawaii|Kailua]], Hawaii, U.S. | workplaces = [[University of California, Los Angeles]]
[[Hawai'i Institute of Marine Biology]] | alma_mater = [[Newcastle University]] (BSc, PhD) | thesis_title = Seawater temperature and algal-cnidarian symbiosis | thesis_url = https://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?uin=uk.bl.ethos.346445 | thesis_year = 1989 | spouse = Robin Burton-Gates | known_for = [[Coral reef]] research | field = [[Marine biology]] | website = {{URL|gatescorallab.com}} }} '''Ruth Deborah Gates''' (March 28, 1962 – October 25, 2018) was the Director of the [[Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology]] and the first woman to be President of the [[International Society for Reef Studies]]. Her research was dedicated to understanding [[coral reef]] ecosystems, specifically coral-algal symbiosis and the capacity for corals to acclimatize under future [[climate change]] conditions.{{Google scholar id}} == Education == Gates was inspired by the documentary ''[[The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/04/18/a-radical-attempt-to-save-the-reefs-and-forests|title=A Radical Attempt to Save the Reefs and Forests|work=The New Yorker|last=Kolbert|first=Elizabeth|date=2016-04-18|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} She studied biology at [[Newcastle University]] where she earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in 1984.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/ruth-gates|title=Ruth Gates|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} She fell in love with corals during a diving trip to the [[West Indies]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.hawaiibusiness.com/20-for-the-next-20-2016/|title=20 for the Next 20: 2016|date=2016-03-03|work=Hawaii Business Magazine|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} In 1985 she moved to the [[West Indies]] to study corals. She completed her [[PhD]] at [[Newcastle University]] in 1989 on seawater temperature and [[algal]]-[[cnidaria]]n [[symbiosis]].{{cite thesis|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Newcastle upon Tyne|url=https://copac.jisc.ac.uk/id/18918380?style=html|title=Seawater temperature and algal-cnidarian symbiosis|first= Ruth Deborah|last=Gates|date=1989|id={{EThOS|uk.bl.ethos.346445}}|website=jisc.ac.uk|oclc=557254204}} ==Career and research== After her PhD, Gates was appointed a [[postdoctoral researcher]] at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. She spent thirteen years working as a junior researcher in California. She was there during the 1998 [[bleaching event]] that killed more than 15 % of corals across the world. Gates joined the [[Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology]] 2003.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tetiaroasociety.org/ruth-gates|title=Ruth Gates {{!}} Tetiaroa Society|website=www.tetiaroasociety.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} She studied corals and reefs, learning how they function and working on ways to slow their decline. She worked on [[Coconut Island]], trying to identify why some corals survive bleaching.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2012/03/corals-ocean-temperature/|title=Some Corals May Adapt to Warming Seas|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} Her group monitored the ecosystems of coral reefs to understand how a changing environment impacted coral health.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/monitoring-reefs|title=Monitoring Reefs|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} The corals in shallow patches like [[Kāneʻohe Bay]] are subject to high temperatures and irradiance. Alongside seawater temperature, they measure photosynthetic active radiation, salinity and nutrient composition. This allowed them to build [[3D modeling|3D models]] of reefs.{{Citation|last=TheJohnburns84|title=Ke'ei|date=2015-10-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TxZLu7wByKY&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-10-28}} They study the [[symbiodinium]] that live within coral tissues. These provide the corals with energy and are lost during coral bleaching.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/symbiodinium-and-symbioses|title=Symbiodinium and Symbioses|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} They develop new techniques for data analysis and management, including developing EarthCube and CRESCYNT.{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/data-management-and-analysis|title=Data Management and Analysis|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward?AWD_ID=1440342|title=NSF Award Search: Award#1440342 - Earthcube RCN: Coral REef Science & CYberinfrastructure NeTwork (CReSCyNT)|website=www.nsf.gov|access-date=2018-10-28}} Gates was concerned about [[sunscreen]] that contains [[octinoxate]] and [[oxybenzone]], and in 2015 called for it to be banned in Hawaii.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/clip/11941033/that-sunscreen-you-slather-on-it-might-be-damaging-coral|title=That sunscreen you slather on? It might be damaging coral|last=|first=|date=|website=Hawaii News Now|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-28}} These sunscreens were banned in 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-05-04/hawaii-bans-sunscreen-coral-bleaching/9728322|title=Would you change sunscreen if it could help save the Great Barrier Reef?|date=2018-05-04|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-AU}} In 2012 she demonstrated that the choice of symbiotic algae was crucial for how tropical reefs survived environmental stresses.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=125278&org=NSF|title=Tropical Reefs Surviving Environmental Stresses: Corals' Choice of Symbiotic Algae May Hold the Key {{!}} NSF - National Science Foundation|website=www.nsf.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=https://app.dimensions.ai/details/grant/grant.2996203|title=A comprehensive survey of endosymbiotic and free-living Symbiodinium diversity in the corals and reef environments of Hawaii - Dimensions|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} She predicted that more than 90 percent of the world's corals will be dead by 2050.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/environment-90-percent-coral-reefs-die-2050-climate-change-bleaching-pollution-a7626911.html|title=More than 90 percent of coral reefs will die out by 2050|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}} === Super coral === In 2013, she won the [[Paul G. Allen]] Ocean Challenge, a $10,000 prize that allowed her to improve the resilience of vulnerable coral reef ecosystems.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pgaphilanthropies.org/oceanchallenge/|title=OceanChallenge - Home|website=www.pgaphilanthropies.org|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.pgaphilanthropies.org/news/news-articles/press-releases/press-release-the-paul-g-allen-family-foundation-n|title=Press Release - The Paul G. Allen Family Foundation Names Winner of Inaugural Ocean Challenge - Paul G. Allen Philanthropies|website=www.pgaphilanthropies.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} For the proposal, Gates joined [[Madeleine van Oppen]], and used genetic selection to boost resilience to environmental stress.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aims.gov.au/docs/media/latest-releases/-/asset_publisher/8Kfw/content/ocean-prize-for-assisted-coral-evolution|title=About the Australian Institute of Marine Science|author=Anon|website=www.aims.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} They did this by exposing cross-bred corals to successively warmer and more acidic experimental tanks.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/climate/coral-great-barrier-reef.html|title=Building a Better Coral Reef|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/environment/this-coral-must-die/|title=This coral must die|date=2018-07-06|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/hawaiian-coral-evolution-sparks-worldwide-debate|title=Hawaiian coral evolution sparks worldwide debate|date=2016-02-13|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/05/scientists-can-engineer-climate-resistant-coral/|title=The Controversial Race to Breed Climate-Adapted Super Coral|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} She was awarded the [[University of Hawaii]] Board of Regents Medal for Excellence in Research.{{Cite web|url=https://www.hawaii.edu/about/awards/research.php|title=Regents' Medal for Excellence in Research :: University of Hawaii System|last=System|first=University of Hawaii|website=www.hawaii.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} ''Coral Assisted Evolution, a'' $4 million research project, was funded by the [[Paul G. Allen Frontiers Group]].{{Cite web|url=http://coralassistedevolution.com/contact|title=Contact|website=coralassistedevolution.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} This supported Gates' research for four years from 2016, developing ''super corals'' that can withstand climate change.{{Citation|last=Vulcan Inc.|title=Innovator Profiles: Ruth Gates Is Working to Save Coral Reefs|date=2018-02-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmxUXLb539o&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-10-28}} Whilst Gates was concerned about playing with nature, she could not sit by and watch species become extinct without acting.{{Cite news|url=https://www.yaleclimateconnections.org/2016/06/horrifying-research-seeks-to-save-hawaii-coral-reefs/|title='Horrifying' research seeks to save Hawaii reefs » Yale Climate Connections|date=2016-06-28|work=Yale Climate Connections|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} In 2016, Gates was named by [[Hawaii Business]] as one of the top 20 leaders of Hawaii. She explored whether non-super corals could be encouraged to take on new symbionts to improve their ability to withstand high temperatures. If Gates' project is successful, it could save the US $9.9 trillion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/business/article/2149588/saving-worlds-coral-avert-wipeout-irreversible-costs|title=Saving the world’s coral to avert a wipeout of irreversible costs|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} In 2018, the foundation supported a coral reef map, that allowed scientists to monitor corals in unprecedented detail.{{Cite web|url=https://www.planet.com/pulse/planet-paul-g-allen-coral-map/|title=Planet, Paul G. Allen Philanthropies, & Leading Scientists Team Up to Map & Monitor World’s Corals in Unprecedented Detail|website=www.planet.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} === Public engagement === She was elected the president of the [[International Society for Reef Studies]].{{Cite web|url=http://coralreefs.org/society-organisation/officers-and-members-of-council/|title=Officers & Councilors – International Society for Reef Studies|website=coralreefs.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-28}} The ''Super Coral'' proposals were featured in ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'', [[Gizmodo]], [[PBS]], ''[[Newsweek]]'', ''[[Hawaii Business]]'', ''[[National Geographic]]'', the ''[[Huffington post]]'', ''[[New Scientist]]'' and the [[BBC]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030680-600-im-creating-supercharged-corals-to-beat-climate-change/|title=I’m creating supercharged corals to beat climate change|last=Schiffman|first=Richard|work=New Scientist|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90188094/scientists-are-speeding-up-evolution-to-build-climate-change-resistance|title=Scientists are speeding up evolution to build climate change resistance|date=2018-07-18|website=fastcompany.com|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://oceantoday.noaa.gov/fullmoon-scienceofsupercorals/welcome.html|title=The Science of Super Corals - Coral Comeback|website=oceantoday.noaa.gov|language=EN-US|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/super-coral-reefs-climate-change-462172|title=Climate-adapted “super coral” could help revive the world's ailing reefs|date=2016-05-22|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}}{{Citation|title=Super Coral That Can Survive Global Warming|url=http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/news/160323-breeding-super-coral-vin?source=relatedvideo|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20160322-the-women-with-a-controversial-plan-to-save-corals|title=The women with a controversial plan to save corals|last=Riley|first=Alex|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hawaiibusiness.com/hawaiis-super-coral/|title=Hawaii’s Super Coral: Evolution on Fast Forward|date=2018-09-12|work=Hawaii Business Magazine|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} Her work was featured on the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Chasing Coral]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.netflix.com/title/80168188|title=Chasing Coral {{!}} Netflix Official Site|website=www.netflix.com|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.chasingcoral.com/the-team/|title=Team - Chasing Coral|work=Chasing Coral|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencefriday.com/segments/chasing-coral-movie/|title=In The Story Of Dying Coral Reefs, A Call To Action|work=Science Friday|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}}She was an invited speaker at the 2017 [[Aspen Ideas Festival]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.aspenideas.org/speaker/ruth-gates|title=Ruth Gates {{!}} Aspen Ideas Festival|website=Aspen Ideas Festival|language=en|access-date=2018-10-28}} She was featured on the University of Hawai'i Foundation video series in 2018.{{Citation|last=UH Foundation|title=Making a Marine Biologist - Ruth Gates Series|date=2018-02-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZVdAHjRzv8Q&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{Citation|last=UH Foundation|title=Adapt or Die - Ruth Gates Series|date=2018-02-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pSjXQud_174|access-date=2018-10-28}} The Gates lab are involved with a wide range of public engagement and outreach, including hosting students from [[Mo'orea]].{{Cite web|url=http://gatescorallab.com/international-impacts|title=International Impacts|website=gatescorallab.com|access-date=2018-10-28}} She was a member of the [[Tetiaroa]] Society. ==Personal life == Gates was born in Cyprus, the sister of Timothy Gates. Her wife was Robin Burton-Gates. She died from [[brain cancer]] at 56 years old, just five months after its diagnosis.[https://www.civilbeat.org/2018/10/rip-ruth-gates-the-world-loses-a-top-coral-scientist-and-indomitable-spirit/ RIP Ruth Gates: The World Loses A Top Coral Scientist And ‘Indomitable Spirit’], ''[[Honolulu Civil Beat]]'', October 30, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2018/10/optimist-who-believed-saving-corals/574240/|title=The Fight for Corals Loses Its Great Champion|last=Yong|first=Ed||work=The Atlantic|date=2018-10-29|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}} == References == {{Authority control}} [[Category:English biologists]] [[Category:Alumni of Newcastle University]] [[Category:University of Hawaii faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:Environmental scientists]] [[Category:2018 deaths]]

page.title: Sites of Japan’s Meiji Industrial Revolution: Iron and Steel, Shipbuilding and Coal Mining

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{missing information|social media mining itself|date=August 2018}} {{cleanup list|date=August 2018}} }} '''Social media mining''' is the process of obtaining [[big data]] from user-generated content on social media sites and [[mobile apps]] in order to extract patterns, form conclusions about users, and act upon the information, often for the purpose of advertising to users or conducting research. The term is an analogy to the resource extraction process of [[mining]] for rare minerals. Resource extraction mining requires mining companies to sift through vast quantities of raw ore to find the precious minerals; likewise, social media mining requires human data analysts and automated software programs to sift through massive amounts of raw social media data in order to discern patterns and trends relating to social media usage, online behaviours, sharing of content, connections between individuals, online buying behaviour, and more. These patterns and trends are of interest to companies, governments and not-for-profit organizations, as these organizations can use these patterns and trends to design their strategies or introduce new programs, new products, processes or services.
Social media mining uses a range of basic concepts from [[computer science]], [[data mining]], [[machine learning]] and [[statistics]]. Social media miners develop [[algorithm]]s suitable for investigating massive files of social media data. Social media mining is based on theories and methodologies from [[social network analysis]], [[network science]], [[sociology]], [[ethnography]], optimization and mathematics. It encompasses the tools to formally represent, measure and model meaningful patterns from large-scale social media data.<ref name="Zafarani">{{cite web |last1=Zafarani |first1=Reza |last2=Abbasi |first2=Mohammad Ali |last3=Liu |first3=Huan |title=Social Media Mining: An Introduction |year=2014 |url=http://dmml.asu.edu/smm |accessdate = 15 November 2014 }}</ref> In the 2010s, major corporations, governments and not-for-profit organizations engaged in social media mining to obtain data about customers, clients and citizens.
==Background==
As defined by Kaplan and Haenlein,<ref name="Kaplan">{{Cite journal |last1=Kaplan |first1=Andreas M. |last2=Haenlein |first2=Michael|title=Users of the world, unite! The challenges and opportunities of social media |year=2010 |journal = Business Horizons | volume = 53 | issue = 1 }}</ref> social media is the "group of internet-based applications that build on the ideological and technological foundations of Web 2.0, and that allow the creation and exchange of user-generated content." There are many categories of social media including, but not limited to, social networking (Facebook or LinkedIn), microblogging (Twitter), photo sharing (Flickr, Photobucket, or Picasa), news aggregation (Google reader, StumbleUpon, or Feedburner), video sharing (YouTube, MetaCafe), livecasting (Ustream or Twitch.tv), virtual worlds (Kaneva), social gaming (World of Warcraft), social search (Google, Bing, or Ask.com), and instant messaging (Google Talk, Skype, or Yahoo! messenger).
The first social media website was introduced by [[GeoCities]] in 1994. It enabled users to create their own homepages without having a sophisticated knowledge of [[HTML]] coding. The first social networking site, [[SixDegrees.com]], was introduced in 1997. Since then, many other social media sites have been introduced, each providing service to millions of people. These individuals form a virtual world in which individuals (social atoms), entities (content, sites, etc.) and interactions (between individuals, between entities, between individuals and entities) coexist. Social norms and human behavior govern this virtual world. By understanding these social norms and models of human behavior and combining them with the observations and measurements of this virtual world, one can systematically analyze and mine social media. Social media mining is the process of representing, analyzing, and extracting meaningful patterns from data in social media, resulting from social interactions. It is an interdisciplinary field encompassing techniques from computer science, data mining, machine learning, social network analysis, network science, sociology, ethnography, statistics, optimization, and mathematics. Social media mining faces grand challenges such as the big data paradox, obtaining sufficient samples, the noise removal fallacy, and evaluation dilemma. Social media mining represents the virtual world of social media in a computable way, measures it, and designs models that can help us understand its interactions. In addition, social media mining provides necessary tools to mine this world for interesting patterns, analyze information diffusion, study influence and homophily, provide effective recommendations, and analyze novel social behavior in social media.
== Uses ==
Social media mining is used across several industries including business development, social science research, health services, and educational purposes.<ref name="dmml.asu.edu">Zafarani, R., Ali Abbasi, M., Liu, H., (2014). Social Media Mining. Cambridge University Press. http://dmml.asu.edu/smm.</ref><ref>Singh, A., (2017). "Mining of Social Media data of University students." ''Education and Information Technologies'', 22: 1515-1526.</ref> Once the data received goes through [[social media analytics]], it can then be applied to these various fields. Often, companies use the patterns of connectivity that pervade social networks, such as assortativity—the social similarity between users that are induced by influence, homophily, and reciprocity and transitivity.<ref name="Tang, J. 2016">Tang, J., Chang, Y., Aggarwal, C., Liu, H., (2016). "A Survey of Signed Network Mining in Social Media". ''ACM Computing Surveys'', 49: 3.</ref> These forces are then measured via statistical analysis of the nodes and connections between these nodes.<ref name="dmml.asu.edu"/> Social analytics also uses [[sentiment analysis]], because social media users often relay positive or negative sentiment in their posts.<ref name="Adedoyin-Olowe, M. 2013">Adedoyin-Olowe, M., Gaber, M., & Stahl, F., (2013). "A Survey of Data Mining Techniques for Social Media Analysis."</ref> This provides important social information about users' emotions on specific topics.<ref>Laeeq, F., Nafis, T., & Beg, M. (2017). "Sentimental Classification of Social Media using Dating Mining." ''International Journal of Advanced Research in Computer Science'', 8: 5.</ref>
These three patterns have several uses beyond pure analysis. For example, influence can be used to determine the most influential user in a particular network.<ref name="dmml.asu.edu"/> Companies would be interested in this information in order to decide who they may hire for [[influencer marketing]]. These influencers are determined by recognition, activity generation, and novelty—three requirements that can be measured through the data mined from these sites.<ref name="dmml.asu.edu"/> Analysts also value measures of homophily: the tendency of two similar individuals to become friends.<ref name="Tang, J. 2016"/> Users have begun to rely on information of other users' opinions in order to understand diverse subject matter.<ref name="Adedoyin-Olowe, M. 2013"/> These analyses can also help create recommendations for individuals in a tailored capacity.<ref name="dmml.asu.edu"/> By measuring influence and homophily, online and offline companies are able to suggest specific products for individuals consumers, and groups of consumers. Social media networks can use this information themselves to suggest to their users possible friends to add, pages to follow, and accounts to interact with.
==Research== ===Research areas=== * Social media event detection<!--/identification--> – Social networks enable users to freely communicate with each other and share their recent news, ongoing activities or views about different topics. As a result, they can be seen as a potentially viable source of information to understand the current emerging topics/events.<ref name="Zarrinkalam">{{cite journal|last1=Zarrinkalam|first1=Fattane|last2=Bagheri|first2=Ebrahim|title=Event identification in social networks|journal=Encyclopedia with Semantic Computing and Robotic Intelligence|date=2017|volume=01|issue=1|pages=1630002|doi=10.1142/S2425038416300020|arxiv=1606.08521}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last1=Nurwidyantoro|first1=A.|last2=Winarko|first2=E.|title=Event detection in social media: A survey|journal=International Conference on ICT for Smart Society|date=1 June 2013|pages=1–5|doi=10.1109/ICTSS.2013.6588106|isbn=978-1-4799-0145-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Event Detection from Social Media Data|url=http://sites.computer.org/debull/A13sept/p51.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Event Detection in Social Media Data|url=https://ai2-s2-pdfs.s3.amazonaws.com/d513/d05dffbb83dbe4d3a2f9d221eb81323e3466.pdf|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Cordeiro|first1=Mário|last2=Gama|first2=João|chapter=Online Social Networks Event Detection: A Survey|title=Solving Large Scale Learning Tasks. Challenges and Algorithms|publisher=Springer International Publishing|pages=1–41|date=1 January 2016|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-41706-6_1|isbn=978-3-319-41705-9}}</ref> * [[Public health surveillance | Public health monitoring and surveillance]] - Using large-scale analysis of social media to study large cohorts of patients and the general public, e.g. to obtain early warning signals of drug-drug interactions and adverse drug reactions<ref name="r26">R.B. Correia, L. Li, L.M. Rocha "[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4720984/ Monitoring potential drug interactions and reactions via network analysis of Instagram user timelines]". ''Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing.'', '''21''':492-503. doi: 10.1142/9789814749411_0045, 2016</ref><ref name="r27">Korkontzelos, I., Nikfarjam, A., Shardlow, M., Sarker, A., Ananiadou, S., & Gonzalez, G. H. "[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1532046416300508 Analysis of the effect of sentiment analysis on extracting adverse drug reactions from tweets and forum posts]". ''Journal of biomedical informatics.'', '''62''':148-158. doi: 10.1016/j.jbi.2016.06.007, 2016</ref>, or understand human reproduction and sexual interest<ref name="r25">I.B Wood, P.L. Varela, J. Bollen, L.M. Rocha, J. Gonçalves-Sá "[https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-18262-5 Human Sexual Cycles are Driven by Culture and Match Collective Moods]". ''Scientific Reports.'', '''7''':17973. doi: 10.1038/s41598-017-18262-5, 2017</ref>. * [[Community structure]] (Community Detection/Evolution/Evaluation) – Identifying communities on social networks, how they evolve, and evaluating identified communities, often without ground truth.<ref name="Zafarani" /> * [[Social network analysis|Network measures]] – Measuring centrality, transitivity, reciprocity, balance, status, and similarity in social media.<ref name="Zafarani" /> * [[Network model]]s – Simulate networks with specific characteristics. Examples include random graphs (E-R models), Preferential attachment models, and small-world models.<ref name="Zafarani" /> * [[Information cascade]] – Analyzing how information propagates in social media sites. Examples include herd behavior, information cascades, diffusion of innovations, and epidemic models.<ref name="Zafarani" /> * [[Social influence|Influence]] and [[homophily]] – Measuring network assortativity and measuring and modeling influence and homophily.<ref name="Zafarani" /> * [[Recommender system|Recommendation in social media]] – recommending friends or items on social media sites.<ref name="Zafarani" /><ref name="Tang-etal14a">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang|first1=Jiliang|last2=Tang|first2=Jie|last3=Liu|first3=Huan| title= Recommendation in Social Media - Recent Advances and New Frontiers|year=2014 |journal = In Proceedings of the 20th ACM SIGKDD Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/Recommendation.htm}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal13a">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang|first1=Jiliang|last2=Hu|first2=Xia|last3=Liu|first3=Huan| title= Social Recommendation: A Review|year=2013 |journal = Social Network Analysis and Mining|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/socialrecommendationreview.pdf}}</ref> * [[Social search]] – Searching for information on the social web.<ref name="Hor-etal10a">{{Cite journal |last1=Horowitz|first1=Damon |last2=Kamvar |first2=Sepandar | title=The Anatomy of a Large-Scale Social Search Engine|year=2013 |journal = In Proceedings of the 19th International Conference on World Wide Web, Pp. 431-440. ACM, 2010 |url=http://www.ra.ethz.ch/cdstore/www2010/www/p431.pdf}}</ref> * [[Sentiment analysis|Sentiment analysis in social media]] – Identifying collectively subjective information, e.g. positive and negative, from social media data.<ref name="Hu-etal13a">{{Cite journal |last1=Hu |first1=Xia |last2=Tang |first2=Lei |last3=Tang |first3=Jiliang |last4=Liu |first4=Huan | title=Exploiting Social Relations for Sentiment Analysis in Microblogging |year=2013 |journal = In Proceedings of the 6th ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~xiahu/papers/wsdm13Hu.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Hu-etal13c">{{Cite journal |last1=Hu |first1=Xia |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |last3=Gao |first3=Huiji |last4=Liu |first4=Huan | title=Unsupervised Sentiment Analysis with Emotional Signals |year=2013 |journal = In Proceedings of the 22nd International World Wide Web Conference |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~xiahu/papers/www13.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ali|first1=K|last2=Dong|first2=H|last3=Bouguettaya|first3=A|title=Sentiment Analysis as a Service: A social media based sentiment analysis framework|journal=The 24th IEEE International Conference on Web Services (IEEE ICWS 2017)|date=2017|pages=660–667|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/319533899}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shahheidari|first1=S|last2=Dong|first2=H|last3=Daud|first3=R|title=Twitter sentiment mining: A multi domain analysis|journal=2013 Seventh International Conference on Complex, Intelligent, and Software Intensive Systems (CISIS 2013)|date=2013|pages=144–149|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/261248570}}</ref><ref name="r25"/><ref name="r27"/> * [[Social spam|Social spammer detection]] – Detecting social spammers who send out unwanted spam content appearing on social networks and any website with user-generated content to targeted users, often corroborating to boost their social influence, legitimacy, credibility.<ref name="Hu-etal13d">{{Cite journal |last1=Hu |first1=Xia |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |last3=Zhang |first3=Yanchao |last4=Liu |first4=Huan | title=Social Spammer Detection in Conference on Artificial Intelligence |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~xiahu/papers/aaai2014.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Hu-etal14b">{{Cite journal |last1=Hu |first1=Xia |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~xiahu/papers/Hu-etal14c.pdf}}</ref> *[[Feature selection|Feature selection with social media data]] – Transforming feature selection to harness the power of social media.<ref name="Tang-etal12a">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang |first1=Jiliang |last2=Liu |first2=Huan| title=Feature Selection with Linked Data in Social Media |year=2012 |journal = In Proceedings of SIAM International Conference on Data Mining |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/feature%20selection%20with%20linked%20data%20in%20social%20media.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal14b">{{Cite |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/LUFS_TKDE.pdf}}</ref> *[[Trust (social sciences)|Trust in social media]] – Studying and understanding of trust in social media.<ref name="Tang-etal14d">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang |first1=Jiliang|last2=Liu |first2=Huan| title=Trust in Social Computing |year=2014 |journal = In Proceedings of the 23rd International World Wide Web Conference |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/tTrust.htm}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal12c">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang |first1=Jiliang |last2=Gao |first2=Huiji|last3=Liu |first3=Huan| title=mTrust: Mining|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/mTrust.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal12d">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang |first1=Jiliang |last2=Gao |first2=Huiji|last3= Discovery and Data Mining |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/trustEvolution.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal13b">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang |first1=Jiliang |last2=Gao
