Mining |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/hTrust.pdf}}</ref> *Distrust and negative links – Exploring negative links in social media.<ref name="Tang-etal14e">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang|first1=Jiliang|last2=Hu|first2=Xia|last3=Liu|first3=Huan| title=Is Distrust the Negation of Trust? The Value of Distrust in Social Media |year=2014 |journal = In Proceedings of ACM Hypertext Conference |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/ValueofDistrust.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal14f">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang|first1=Jiliang|last2=Hu|first2=Xia|last3=Chang|first3=Yi|last4=Liu|first4=Huan| title=Predictability of Distrust with Interaction Data |year=2014|journal = ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/km0131-tang.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Tang-etal15a">{{Cite journal |last1=Tang |first1=Jiliang |last2=Chang |first2=Shiyu|last3= Aggarwal|first3=Charu|last4=Liu |first4=Huan| title = Negative Link Prediction in Social Media |year=2015 |journal = In Proceedings OfACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~jtang20/publication/negative_link_prediction.pdf}}</ref> *Role of [[social media]] in [[crisis|crises]] – Social media is continuing to play an important role during crises, particularly Twitter.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bruno|first1=Nicola|title=Tweet first, verify later? How real-time information is changing the coverage of worldwide crisis events|journal=Oxford: Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism, University of Oxford|date=2011|volume=10|pages=2010–2011}}</ref> Studies show that it is possible to detect earthquakes<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sakaki|first1=Takashi|last2=Okazaki|first2=Makoto|last3=Yutaka|first3=Matsuo|title=Earthquake shakes Twitter users: real-time event detection by social sensors|journal=Proceedings of the 19th International Conference on World Wide Web|date=2010|pages=851–860}}</ref> and rumors<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mendoza|first1=Marcelo|last2=Poblete|first2=Barbara|last3=Castillo|first3=Carlos|title=Twitter under crisis: Can we trust what we RT?|journal=Proceedings of the First Workshop on Social Media Analytics|date=2010|pages=71–79}}</ref> using tweets published during crisis. Developing tools to help first responders to analyze tweets towards better crisis response<ref name=Kuma-etal11>{{cite journal|last1=Kumar|first1=Shamanth|last2=Barbier|first2=Geoffrey|last3=Abbasi|first3=Mohammad Ali|last4=Liu|first4=Huan|title=TweetTracker: An Analysis Tool for Humanitarian and Disaster Relief|journal=The 5th International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media|date=2011|url=http://www.aaai.org/ocs/index.php/ICWSM/ICWSM11/paper/download/2736/3201|accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref> and developing techniques to provide them faster access to relevant tweets<ref name=Kuma-etal14>{{cite journal|last1=Kumar|first1=Shamanth|last2=Hu|first2=Xia|last3=Liu|first3=Huan|title=A behavior analytics approach to identifying tweets from crisis regions|journal=Proceedings of the 25th ACM Conference on Hypertext and Social Media|date=2014|pages=255–260}}</ref> is an active area of research. *Location-based social network mining – Mining Human Mobility for Personalized POI Recommendation on Location-based Social Networks.<ref name="Gao-etal12a">{{Cite journal |last1=Gao |first1=Huiji |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |last3=Liu |first3=Huan| title=Exploring Social-Historical Ties on Location-Based Social Networks |year=2012 |journal = In Proceedings of the Sixth International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~hgao16/papers/icwsm2012SocialHistoricalTies.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Gao-etal12b">{{Cite journal |last1=Gao |first1=Huiji |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |last3=Liu |first3=Huan| title=Mobile Location Prediction in Spatio-Temporal Context |year=2012 |journal = Nokia Mobile Data Challenge Workshop 2012 |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~hgao16/papers/nokiachallenge.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Gao-etal12c">{{Cite journal |last1=Gao |first1=Huiji |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |last3=Liu |first3=Huan| Knowledge Management |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~hgao16/papers/sp171-gao.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Gao-etal13">{{Cite journal |last1=Gao |first1=Huiji |last2=Tang |first2=Jiliang |last3=Hu |first3=Xia |last4=Liu |first4=Huan| title=Exploring Temporal Effects for Location Recommendation on Location-Based Social Networks |year=2013 |journal = In Proceedings of the 7th ACM Recommender Systems |first3=Huan| title=Personalized Location Recommendation on Location-based Social Networks |year=2014 |journal = In Proceedings of the 8th ACM Recommender Systems Conference |url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~hgao16/papers/RecSys-Tutorial-Gao-Tang-Liu-20141006.pdf}}</ref> *Provenance of information in social media – [[Provenance]] informs a user about the sources of a given piece of information. Social media can help in identifying the provenance of information due its unique features: user-generated content, user profiles, user interactions, and spatial or temporal information.<ref name="Barb-etal13">{{Cite journal |last1=Barbier |first1=Geoffrey |last2=Feng |first2=Zhuo |last3=Gundecha |first3=Pritam |last4=Liu |first4=Huan |title=Provenance Data in Social Media |year=2013 |journal=Synthesis Lectures on Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery |volume=4 |pages=1–84 |doi=10.2200/S00496ED1V01Y201304DMK007 }}</ref><ref name="Gund-etal13">{{Cite journal |last1=Gundecha |first1=Pritam |last2=Feng |first2=Zhuo |last3=Liu |first3=Huan |title=Seeking Provenance of Information in Social Media |year=2013 |journal= In Proceedings of the 22nd ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management Conference|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/%7Epgundech//papers/pritamCIKM13a.pdf}}</ref> *[[Vulnerability management]] – A user's [[vulnerability]] on a social networking sites can be managed in three sequential steps: (1) identifying new ways in which a user can be vulnerable, (2) quantifying or measuring a user's vulnerability, and (3) reducing or mitigating them.<ref name="Gund-etal14">{{Cite journal |last1=Gundecha |first1=Pritam |last2=Barbier |first2=Geoffrey |last3=Tang |first3=Jiliang |last4=Liu |first4=Huan |title=User Vulnerability and its Reduction on a Social Networking Site |year=2014 |journal= Journals of Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data| url=http://www.public.asu.edu/%7Epgundech//papers/pritamTKDD14.pdf}}</ref>
=== Publication venues===
Social media mining research articles are published in computer science, social science, and data mining conferences and journals:
====Conferences====
Conference papers can be found in proceedings of Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (KDD), World Wide Web (WWW), Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL), Conference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM), International Conference on Data Mining (ICDM), Internet Measuring Conference (IMC).
* [[KDD Conference]] – ACM SIGKDD [[Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining]] * [[WWW Conference]] – [[International World Wide Web Conference]] * WSDM Conference – ACM Conference on Web Search and Data Mining * [[CIKM Conference]] – ACM [[Conference on Information and Knowledge Management]] * ICDM Conference – [[IEEE]] International Conference on Data Mining * [[Association for Computational Linguistics|Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL)]] * Internet Measuring Conference (IMC) * International Conference on Weblogs and Social Media (ICWSM) * International Conference on Web Engineering (ICWE) * The European Conference on Machine Learning and Principles and Practice of Knowledge Discovery in Databases(ECML/PKDD), * International Joint Conferences on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI), * Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI), * Recommender Systems (RecSys) * Computer-Human Interaction (CHI) * Social Computing Behavioral-Cultural Modeling and Prediction (SBP). * HT Conference – ACM Conference on Hypertext * SDM Conference – SIAM International Conference on Data Mining ([[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]]) * PAKDD Conference – The annual Pacific-Asia Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining
====Journals====
* DMKD Conference – Research Issues on Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery * ECML-PKDD Conference – [[European Conference on Machine Learning and Principles and Practice of Knowledge Discovery in Databases]] * IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering (TKDE), * ACM Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data (TKDD) * ACM Transactions on Intelligent Systems and Technology (TIST) * Social Network Analysis and Mining (SNAM) * Knowledge and Information Systems (KAIS) * ACM Transactions on the Web (TWEB) * World Wide Web Journal * Social Networks * Internet Mathematics * IEEE Intelligent Systems * SIGKDD Exploration.
Social media mining is also present on many [[List of computer science conferences#Data Management|data management/database conferences]] such as the ICDE Conference, [[SIGMOD|SIGMOD Conference]] and [[International Conference on Very Large Data Bases]].

'''Social physics''' or '''sociophysics''' is a field of science which uses mathematical tools inspired by [[physics]] to understand the behavior of human crowds. In a modern commercial use, it can also refer to the analysis of social phenomena with [[big data]]. Social physics is closely related to [[econophysics]] which uses physics methods to describe [[economics]]. ==History== The first elements of social physics were outlined in French social thinker [[Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon|Henri de Saint-Simon]]’s first book, the 1803 ''Lettres d’un Habitant de Geneve'', which described the idea of describing society using laws similar to those of the physical and biological sciences.{{Cite journal|last=Iggers|first=Georg G.|year=1959|title=Further Remarks about Early Uses of the Term "Social Science"|jstor=2708121|journal=Journal of the History of Ideas|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|volume=20|issue=3|pages=433–436|doi=10.2307/2708121}} His student and collaborator was [[Auguste Comte]], a French philosopher widely regarded as the founder of [[sociology]], who first defined the term in an essay appearing in ''Le Producteur'', a journal project by Saint-Simon. Comte defined social physics as
Social physics is that science which occupies itself with social phenomena, considered in the same light as astronomical, physical, chemical, and physiological phenomena, that is to say as being subject to natural and invariable laws, the discovery of which is the special object of its researches.
After Saint-Simon and Comte, Belgian statistician [[Adolphe Quetelet]], proposed that society be modeled using [[mathematical probability]] and [[social statistics]]. Quetelet's 1835 book, ''Essay on Social Physics: Man and the Development of his Faculties'', outlines the project of a social physics characterized by measured variables that follow a [[normal distribution]], and collected data about many such variables.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1v8OAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Sur+l%27homme+et+le+d%C3%A9veloppement+de+ses+facult%C3%A9s,+ou+Essai+de+physique+sociale&ei=gAuuS_OPJZ7WMO2TvZcM&cd=2#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=Sur l'homme et le Développement de ses Facultés, ou Essai de Physique Sociale|last=Quetelet|first=Adolphe|publisher=Imprimeur-Libraire|year=1835|isbn=|volume=1-2|location=Paris|pages=|language=French|trans-title=Essay on Social Physics: Man and the Development of his Faculties|quote=|via=}} A frequently repeated anecdote is that when Comte discovered that Quetelet had appropriated the term 'social physics', he found it necessary to invent a new term 'sociologie' (sociology) because he disagreed with Quetelet's collection of statistics. There have been several “generations” of social physicists.{{Cite journal|last=Iberall|first=Arthur|year=1984|orig-year=Presented at Annual Conference of the International Society for the Comparative Study of Civilizations (ISCSC), Syracuse, May 1980|title=Contributions to a Physical Science for the Study of Civilizations|journal=Journal of Social and Biological Structures|volume=7|issue=3|pages=259–283}} The first generation began with Saint-Simon, Comte, and Quetelet, and ended with the late 1800s with historian [[Henry Adams]]. In the middle of the 20th century, researchers such as the American astrophysicist [[John Q. Stewart]] and Swedish geographer [[Reino Ajo]],{{Cite book|title=Contributions to "Social Physics": a Programme Sketch with Special Regard to National Planning|last=Ajo|first=Reino|publisher=Royal University of Lund|year=1953|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} who showed that the spatial distribution of social interactions could be described using gravity models. Physicists such as [[Arthur Iberall]] use a [[homeokinetics]] approach to study social systems as complex self-organizing systems.{{Cite journal|last=Iberall|first=A|year=1985|title=Outlining social physics for modern societies - locating culture, economics, and politics: The Enlightenment reconsidered|journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci USA |volume=82|pages=5582–84|doi=10.1073/pnas.82.17.5582|pmc=390594}}{{Cite journal|last1=Iberall|first1=A|last2=Hassler|first2=F|last3=Soodak|first3=H|last4=Wilkinson|first4=D|year=2000|title=Invitation to an Enterprise: From Physics to World History to Civilizations’ Study|journal=Comparative Civilization Review|volume=42|pages=4–22}} For example, a homeokinetics analysis of society shows that one must account for flow variables such as the flow of energy, of materials, of action, reproduction rate, and value-in-exchange.{{citation|last=Iberall| first=Arthur S.|title=Homeokinetics: The Basics|publisher=Strong Voices Publishing|year=2016|location=Medfield, MA|isbn=978-0-990-53614-7}} More recently there have been a large number of social science papers that use mathematics broadly similar to that of [[physics]], and described as “[[computational social science]]”.Lazer, D., Pentland, A., et al ''Science'' 2010 In the late 1800s, Adams separated “human physics” into the subsets of social physics or social mechanics (sociology of interactions using physics-like mathematical tools){{Cite journal|last=Ball|first=Phillip|year=2002|orig-year=A talk presented at ‘Horizons in Complex Systems’ Messina, Sicily, Italy, 2001|title=The physical modelling of society: a historical perspective|url=http://www.if.ufrj.br/~mbr/econofisica/intro/artigos/Physica.A.314.1.2002.pdf|journal=Physica A|volume=314|issue=1-4|pages=1–14|doi=10.1016/s0378-4371(02)01042-7}} and social thermodynamics or sociophysics, (sociology described using mathematical invariances similar to those in [[thermodynamics]]).{{Cite journal|last=Wilson|first=Alan|title=Notes on Some Concepts in Social Physics|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1435-5597.1969.tb01460.x/abstract|journal=Regional Science|publisher=Regional Science Association International|volume=22|issue=1|pages=159–193|doi=10.1111/j.1435-5597.1969.tb01460.x}} This dichotomy is roughly analogous to the difference between [[microeconomics]] and [[macroeconomics]]. ==Recent work== In modern use “social physics” refers to using “[[big data]]” analysis and the mathematical laws to understand the behavior of human crowds.{{Cite journal|last=GEORGE|first=Gerard|last2=HAAS|first2=Martine R.|last3=PENTLAND|first3=Alex|year=2014|title=Big Data and Management: From the Editors|url=http://ink.library.smu.edu.sg/lkcsb_research/4621/|journal=Academy of Management Journal|volume=57|issue=2|pages=321–326|doi=10.5465/amj.2014.4002}} The core idea is that data about human activity (e.g., phone call records, credit card purchases, taxi rides, web activity) contain mathematical patterns that are characteristic of how social interactions spread and converge. These mathematical invariances can then serve as a filter for analysis of behavior changes and for detecting emerging behavioral patterns.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ibm.com/analytics/us/en/technology/predictive-analytics/|title=Predictive Analytics|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Recent books about social physics include [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] Professor [[Alex Pentland]]’s book ''Social Physics''{{Cite book|title=Social Physics: How Good Ideas Spread—the Lessons from a New Science|last=Pentland|first=Alex|publisher=Penguin|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} or [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] editor [[Mark Buchanan]]’s book ''The Social Atom''.{{Cite book|title=The Social Atom - why the Rich get Richer, Cheaters get Caught, and Your Neighbor Usually Looks Like You|last=Buchanan|first=Mark|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|year=2007|isbn=|location=|pages=x - xi|quote=|via=}} Popular reading about sociophysics include English physicist [[Philip Ball]]’s ''Why Society is a Complex Matter''{{Cite book|title=Why Society is a Complex Matter: Meeting Twenty-First Century Challenges with a New Kind of Science|last=Ball|first=Philip|publisher=Springer|year=2012|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}, [[Dirk Helbing]]'s ''The Automation of Society is next'' or American physicist [[Albert-László Barabási|Lazlo Barabasi]]’s book ''Linked''.{{Cite book|title=Linked: The New Science of Networks|last=Barabási|first=Albert-László|publisher=Perseus Books Group|year=2002|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}} ==Blockchain, Cryptography, and Social Physics Applications== Over the past few years, Social Physics has been shown to be a potent analytics tool for a variety of applications where either data is anonymized or only metadata is available, as is typical of crytographic and [[blockchain]] systems. This is because Social Physics is primarily about interactions between elements, so that the form of the data is often irrelevant. Following are a few examples for the use of Social Physics applied to Blockchain and Crypto systems: * Social Physics for Financial Interaction. In a recent MIT PhD [http://people.csail.mit.edu/pkrafft/papers/krafft-thesis-final.pdf Thesis], a social physics approach to [[cryptocurrency]] market buy/sell timing was shown to drive “bubbles” in [[AltCoin|AltCoins]]. In this experiment, carefully timed investments totaling just a few dollars often drove more than 5000 times increase in AltCoin market value. * Social Physics for breaking cryptographic anonymization. A recent ruling of the US Supreme Court cited the use of Social Physics for the efficient re-identification of cryptographically anonymized metadata (similar to [[Bitcoin]] transactions), discouraging defense agencies and private companies from collecting and using this so-called "anonymized" data{{Cite journal|last=Montjoye|first=Yves-Alexandre de|last2=Radaelli|first2=Laura|last3=Singh|first3=Vivek Kumar|last4=Pentland|first4=Alex “Sandy”|date=2015-01-30|title=Unique in the shopping mall: On the reidentifiability of credit card metadata|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/347/6221/536|journal=Science|language=en|volume=347|issue=6221|pages=536–539|doi=10.1126/science.1256297|issn=0036-8075|pmid=25635097}}. * Social Physics for Anti-Money Laundering (AML). Social Physics was used to uncover a collaborating network of bitcoin addresses, an arrangement often used to launder stolen Bitcoins. This was done using a handful of known malicious addresses, that were used as “seeds” for the Social Physics “behavioral similarity detection” algorithm, resulting in an accurate detection of dozens of additional members of the network{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1003255394|title=New solutions for cybersecurity|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Shrobe, Howard E.,, Shrier, David L.,, Pentland, Alex, 1952-|year=|isbn=9780262535373|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=|chapter=11|oclc=1003255394}}. ==Commercial use== Most recently, research by [[Alex Pentland|Prof. Alex “Sandy” Pentland]] and [[Yaniv Altshuler|Dr Yaniv Altshuler]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] has combined social physics with [[Machine learning|Machine Learning]] to improve the performance of machine learning applications.{{Cite web|url=https://www.media.mit.edu/research/highlights/tuning-social-networks-gain-wisdom-crowd|title=Tuning Social Networks to Gain the Wisdom of the Crowd {{!}} MIT Media Lab|website=www.media.mit.edu|access-date=2016-10-21}} [http://www.endor.com Endor], a company co-founded by [[Yaniv Altshuler|Dr. Altshuler]], utilized social physics to introduce a predictive intelligence platform that automates the process of answering predictive business questions, using natural language{{Cite news|url=http://news.mit.edu/2017/endor-inventing-google-predictive-analytics-1220|title=Inventing the “Google” for predictive analytics|work=MIT News|access-date=2017-12-26}}. A ICO of 50 million USD was also conducted by Endor. In the field of [[cyber-security]], a team headed by [[Yaniv Altshuler|Dr Altshuler]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] has shown how the concept of social physics, manifested as mathematical invariances that are embedded in large datasets, can be used in order to generate new and highly efficient types of attacks on behavioral information.{{Cite journal|last=Altshuler|first=Yaniv|last2=Aharony|first2=Nadav|last3=Pentland|first3=Alex|last4=Elovici|first4=Yuval|last5=Cebrian|first5=Manuel|year=2011|title=Stealing Reality: When Criminals Become Data Scientists (or Vice Versa)|url=http://web.media.mit.edu/~yanival/IEEE_Intelligent_Systems.pdf|journal=IEEE Intelligent Systems|volume=26|issue=6}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Branches of physics}} [[Category:Sociophysics| ]] [[Category:Big data]] [[Category:Blockchains]]

{{primary sources|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox university |name = University of Belgrade
Faculty of Political Sciences |native_name = Факултет политичких наука
Универзитета у Београду
Fakultet političkih nauka
Univerziteta u Beogradu |image_name = |image_size = |image_alt = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |mottoeng = |established = 1968 |closed = |type = [[Public university|Public]] |affiliation = |endowment = |officer_in_charge = |chairman = |chancellor = |president = |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = |rector = |principal = |dean = Prof. dr Dragan R. Simić |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 90 |staff = |students = 3,500 |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Belgrade]] |country = [[Serbia]] |coor = {{coord|44.773663|20.475832|display=inline, title|type:edu}} |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] |former_names = |free_label = |free = |sports = |colors = Blue and White {{color box|blue}}{{color box|white}} |colours = |nickname = FPN |mascot = |athletics = |affiliations = [[University of Belgrade]] |website = [http://www.fpn.bg.ac.rs www.fpn.bg.ac.rs] |logo = |footnotes = }} The '''Faculty of Political Sciences''' ({{lang-sr| Факултет политичких наука Универзитета у Београду / Fakultet političkih nauka Univerziteta u Beogradu}}, abbreviated FPN) is a constituent institution of the [[University of Belgrade]] which focuses on education and research in the fields of political science, international relations, journalism and communication studies, and social policy and social work. It was established in 1968, as a first faculty of this type in former Yugoslavia. The building, built in the [[Brutalist architecture|Brutalist]] style, is located in the urban neighborhood of [[Voždovac]], close to the Faculty of Organizational Sciences. The Faculty of Political Sciences offers [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Master of Arts|MA]] and [[PhD]] programmes, as well as advanced professional development programmes. ==History== The Faculty of Political Sciences was established in 1968, after the National Assembly of Serbia brought an establishment act.{{Citation|url=http://www.bg.ac.rs/files/sr/univerzitet/glasnik-zakoni/zbornik/knjiga3/3_119.pdf |title=ZAKON O FAKULTETU POLITIČKIH NAUKA U BEOGRADU |language=Serbian |date=1968-11-20}} It was the first institution of its kind in [[former Yugoslavia]]. Since its founding to 2013, it has educated more than 8,100 students, with 975 of them having completed [[Master of Arts|MA]] programmes, and 464 having defended their [[PhD]] theses.{{citation |url=http://www.fpn.bg.ac.rs/en/the-faculty/about-us/ |title=About Us |publisher=Faculty of Political Sciences}} Many of the [[alumni]] have become recognized experts and scholars, professors and high ranking government officials. Many of the faculties of political sciences, established subsequently in other parts of the [[former Yugoslavia]] were formed from the University of Belgrade Faculty of Political Sciences as a core, and a large number of professors at the various faculties of political sciences in all the countries of the [[former Yugoslavia]], had obtained their academic titles at the University of Belgrade Faculty of Political Sciences. Celebration of the faculty's 40th anniversary was held in the hall of the [[National Assembly of Serbia]] in November 2008. It was sponsored by the President of Serbia. An international conference "State and Democracy" was held as a part of anniversary.{{citation|url=http://www.rts.rs/page/stories/sr/story/125/Dru%C5%A1tvo/29858/Jubilej++FPN-a.html |title=Jubilej FPN-a |publisher=Radio Television of Serbia |date=2008-11-27 |language=Serbian}} ==Academic staff== The [[University of Belgrade]] Faculty of Political Sciences has among its academic staff some of the most eminent experts in the field of political sciences, as well as in a range of others ([[economy]], [[sociology]], [[philosophy]], [[law]], [[history]], etc.) Amongst them, there are many widely recognized within the domestic and international academic community, as well as former or current high government officials – Ministers, Ambassadors, etc. Notable members of the academic staff include:{{citation |url=http://www.fpn.bg.ac.rs/en/teachers-and-staff |title=Teachers and Staff |publisher=Faculty of Political Sciences}} *[[Dragan Veselinov]], [[Government of Serbia (2001-2004)|Minister of Agriculture]] (2001-2003) *[[Ivo Visković]], [[Embassy of Serbia in Berlin|Ambassador of Serbia to Germany]] (2009-2013) *[[Slobodan Samardžić]], [[Cabinet of Serbia (2007–2008)|Minister for Kosovo-Metohija]] (2007-2008) *[[Čedomir Čupić]], Chairman of the Board of The Anti-Corruption Agency of the Republic of Serbia (2009-2011) *[[Tanja Miščević]], [[Chief Negotiator]] for [[Serbia’s accession negotiations with the EU]], former [[State secretary]] of the [[Cabinet of Serbia (2008–2012)|Ministry of Defence]] of the Republic of Serbia (2008-2012) ==Student life== Student life at the Faculty includes a diverse array of student activities. Student organisations at the Faculty of Political Sciences include a [[Debate Club]], European Students Forum, Youth Team Initiative [http://timfpn.weebly.com TIM], Serbian Political Forum [http://spf.fpn.bg.ac.rs SPF], United Nations Club, Diplomatic Forum, Action for Political Emancipation of Youth [https://web.archive.org/web/20110806005218/http://apem.org.rs/ APEM] and many others. Students also elect their representatives (Student Vice-Dean and the [[Students' Union|Student Parliament]]) to represent their interests in the Faculty bodies, participate in the evaluation of studies and the faculty, and secure the involvement and participation of students in all matters and issues of interest to them. Students periodically publish their own newspaper – ''Politikolog'' (The Political Scientist), and take part in various competitions through their sports club. Also, students of [[journalism]] prepare radio and TV shows which are broadcast on radios and televisions with national frequencies. ==Professional gatherings== Students have the opportunity to participate in numerous events and gatherings (national and international). Student Conference at [[Kopaonik]] which is held every year provides them with the chance to discuss the most recent developments in both domestic and international politics with prominent experts, professors and diplomats. Study trips that are organized every year include visits to Serbia's diplomatic missions across Europe, [[European Parliament]], [[European Court of Human Rights]], [[United Nations]], [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] and many other institutions. Also, a regional gathering of political sciences students called "Politijada" is being held every year with students from [[Serbia]], [[Montenegro]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Slovenia]] taking part. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.fpn.bg.ac.rs/ Faculty of Political Sciences website] (in Serbian, English) {{University of Belgrade}} [[Category:University of Belgrade schools]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1968]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Belgrade|University of Belgrade Faculty of Political Sciences]] [[Category:University of Belgrade]] [[Category:Education in Belgrade]] [[Category:Education in Serbia]] [[Category:Political science education]] [[Category:Political science in Serbia]]

A '''vector-based graphical user interface''' is a mostly conceptual type of [[graphical user interface]] where elements are drawn using [[Vector graphics|vector]] rather than [[Raster graphics|raster]] information.
[[Image:3D GUI.png|thumb|200px|An example of a vector-based window, found in a privately funded vector-based graphical user interface research project.]]
[[File:2D Vector GUI.png|thumb|2D GUI. All window decorations and elements inside them are vector-based, the background is generated from multiple sine waves and the shapes are defined in-runtime. The final image is rasterized, anti-aliased and optionally composited, here the compositing is disabled.]]
==Pros and cons== The benefits of a completely vector-based graphical user interface would include: :*more efficient, independent scalability; The resolution (measured in [[dots per inch]] or DPI) could be set higher or lower than 1px:1px without causing [[pixelation]], enabling better use of high resolution monitors.
Cons might include: :*Difficulty integrating raster-based applications. With some effort, this could be accomplished by texturing the entire raster-based application to a vector-based plane (though the disadvantages of raster-based graphics would still stand). :*Slower rendering, greater system requirements. Because today's monitors display only raster-based information, the vector information would have to be rasterized (and optionally [[Spatial anti-aliasing|anti-aliased]]) before appearing.
==Usage in 3D graphical user interfaces== Since current [[3D computer graphics|3D Graphics]] are usually vector-based, rather than raster-based, vector-based graphical user interfaces would be suitable for 3D graphical user interfaces. This is because raster-based 3D models take up an enormous amount of memory, as they are stored and displayed using [[voxel]]s. Current [[operating systems]] such as [[Windows Vista]], [[Mac OS X]], and [[UNIX|UNIX-based]] operating systems (including [[Linux]]) have enjoyed much benefit from using 3D graphical user interfaces. In Windows Vista, for example, [[Windows Aero|Flip3D]] textures each window to a 3D plane based on vector graphics. Even though the window itself is still raster-based, the plane onto which it is textured is vector-based. As a result, the windows, when rotated, appear flat. In Linux desktops, [[Compiz Fusion]] can texture each raster-based workspace onto a 3D vector-based cube. As operating systems evolve, eventually the entire window would be made from 3D vector graphics, so that when rotated, it does not appear "flat". Also, advanced lighting may make 3D graphical user interfaces more aesthetically pleasing.
==Usage in 2D graphical user interfaces== As most computer monitors become more and more [[dots per inch|high resolution]], everything displayed would be smaller. However, if the screen resolution were turned down, everything would appear pixelated. Thus, [[resolution independence]] is currently being designed to solve this problem. With raster graphics, all icons need to be extremely high resolution, so as to not appear pixelated on higher resolution screens. This may take up enormous amounts of memory, and hard disk space.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} If vector graphics were used instead, it could be easily scalable and never lose data nor appear pixelated.
Some Graphical User Interfaces on [[Operating System]]s such as [[IRIX]] use vector-based icons. A number of vector-based icon sets are also available for window managers such as [[GNOME]] and [[KDE]].
With Windows, applications built using [[Windows Presentation Foundation]] (which is native{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} to [[Windows Vista]], but can be downloaded for [[Windows XP]] and [[Windows Server 2003|Server 2003]]) are vector-based and scale losslessly based on Windows [[Dots per inch|DPI]] settings. However, even without this, it has always been possible to build applications to be DPI-aware.<ref>[http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms969894.aspx MSDN: How to Write High-DPI Applications]</ref> Additionally, in Vista, the [[Desktop Window Manager]] detects when an app is not DPI aware and, if the computer is set to a different DPI than normal, uses bitmap scaling to render the window at a larger size.<ref>[http://blogs.msdn.com/greg_schechter/archive/2006/08/07/690704.aspx High DPI Support in Windows Vista Aero]</ref>
New version of [[AmigaOS]] 4.1 enhanced in 2008 its [[Workbench (AmigaOS)|Workbench]] with 2D vector graphical interface based on [[Cairo (Graphics)|Cairo]] libraries, but pragmatically integrated it with a 3D Compositing Engine based on [[Alpha Channel|Porter-Duff]] Routines.
==See also== *Sun Microsystems' [[NeWS]] (Network extensible Window System) *[[Dots per inch|DPI]] *[[Resolution independence]]
==References== {{reflist}}
